g.text: Each element has unique predecessor & successor
One element connected to multiple elements
• Elements are arranged in a sequential manner
• Each element has a unique predecessor and successor (except first/last)
• Linked structures: Nodes connected through pointers
• Elements connected in hierarchical or network manner
• One element can be connected to multiple elements
• Efficient for representing complex real-world relationships
LINEAR vs NON-LINEAR DATA STRUCTURES COMPARISON
Sequential arrangement, each element has unique predecessor & successor
Hierarchical or network arrangement, multiple connections possible
Memory efficient, contiguous or linked allocation
More memory overhead due to multiple pointers/connections
Simple traversal in one direction or both directions
Complex traversal algorithms (DFS, BFS, tree traversals)
More complex implementation, requires recursive algorithms
Arrays, Lists, Stacks, Queues, String processing
Data structure choice depends on the specific requirements: access patterns, memory constraints, and operation frequency
Linear structures: Simple, efficient for sequential operations | Non-linear structures: Complex relationships, hierarchical data
